description.para: Continous Availability (CA) is a feature of the underlying file system. Generally speaking, CA may be available on clustered or distributed file systems that allow a connection to fail over to another node in the event of a server crash or reboot.
Continuous availability is only enabled if Persistent Handle support has been negotiated on the connection.

This parameter has three possible values:
Yes: This setting is for testing purposes. If SMB3 or above has been negotiated on the connection, and if Persistent Handle support has also been negotiated on the connection, then the server will indicate CA support on the share in the Tree Connect response whether or not the underling file system actaully supports CA.
Auto: This setting automatically determines whether or not the share supports Continuous Availability. The following conditions must be met:
The negotiated protocol on the connection must be SMB3 or above.
Persistent Handle support must have been negotiated on the connection.
A Samba VFS module that provides Continuous Availability support must have been loaded on the share.
If these conditions are met, then the server will indicate CA support for the share in the Tree Connect response. The VFS module is then responsible for providing that support.
No: Explicitly disables CA support on the share. The server will not indicate CA support to the client and will not provide Persistent Handles for files that are opened within the share.
